page.title: 06Pencombe and its Farms
page.content: The farmholdings are mostly approximately 200 acres with the exception of two smallholdings and three larger holdings of 400 acres. The majority have a mixed husbandary of corn, sheep and beef cattle. There are two dairy farms with herds of about 100 friesians. The two smallholdings are grassland. The main exception is Marston Farm of about 400 acres all planted to poplars by Bryant and May for matches. However because of cheaper imports the trees became worthless and so the farm was sold. At present the owners are felling the trees, the wood being used for pallet making and the grass-keep let to neighbouring farms. The farmstead and cottages have been converted to holiday accomodation.
